This implies that for such curves $\gamma_\epsilon$, $(n-1) \cos \theta \cos \varphi - (m-1)\sin\theta \sin \varphi$ is uniformly  bounded away from $0$ for $t$ near $t_-(\epsilon)$.  In particular, this is true as $\epsilon \searrow 0$.

By the monotonicity of $\varphi$ and $\theta$, it follows that $r(t_+(\epsilon))>R$ as $\epsilon\searrow 0$.  On the other hand, we claim that $r(t_-(\epsilon))\rightarrow 0$ as $\epsilon\searrow 0$.  By the monotonicity of $\varphi$ and $\theta$, there is a unique $t_0(\epsilon) \in (t_-(\epsilon), 0)$ such that $\varphi(t_0) - \theta(t_0) = \frac{\pi}{2}$.  In particular, $r'(t)<0$ for $t<t_0$, $r'(t)>0$ for $t>t_0$ and $r$ attains a global minimum at $t=t_0$. 

By smooth dependence on ODE solutions based on initial conditions, $\gamma_\epsilon$ converges to $\ell_{m,n}$ as $\epsilon\searrow 0$.  Therefore, there is a sequence $\epsilon_n \searrow 0$ such that $|\gamma_{\epsilon_n}(t_0)|<\frac{1}{n}$.  By this and the preceding, it follows from Equation \eqref{eqn: vector field} that $\lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} \theta'(t) = 0$ uniformly for $t\in (t_-(\epsilon_n), t_0(\epsilon_n))$.  Since $\gamma_{\epsilon_n}$ is unit speed parametrized, this implies that $\epsilon_n$ can be chosen such that $|\gamma_{\epsilon_n}(t_-)|< \frac{2}{n}$.  Therefore, $|\gamma_{\epsilon}(t_-)|<|\gamma_{\epsilon}(t_+)|$ as $\epsilon\searrow 0$.  On the other hand, by adapting the argument above as $\epsilon \nearrow \pi$, we find that $|\gamma_{\epsilon}(t_-)|>|\gamma_{\epsilon}(t_+)|$ as $\epsilon \nearrow  \pi$. By continuity, it follows that there is an $\bar{\epsilon} \in (0, \pi)$ such that $|\gamma_{\bar{\epsilon}}(t_-)| = |\gamma_{\bar\epsilon}(t_+)|$.  It follows that the rescaled curve

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex43.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=z_{i}z^{\prime}_{i}+r(z_{i}-c)\dot{r}(z_{i}-c)(z_{i}-c)^{\prime}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>r</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex44.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{z_{i}}{n-1}\left(n-r^{2n-2}\right)." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: and after further calculation,
prevtext:
By Lemma \ref{first derivative positive estimate}, $f_1'(0)> 0$ and $f_2'(0)< 0$. 
We compute the second derivatives in the same way:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex45.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}f^{\prime\prime}_{i}(c)" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>′′</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex45.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{z^{\prime}_{i}}{n-1}(n-r^{2n-2})+\frac{z_{i}}{n-1}\left(-(%
2n-2)r^{2n-3}\dot{r}\frac{d}{dc}(z_{i}-c)\right)" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msubsup><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>r</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex46.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n-1}\left((2n-2)r^{2n-2}+z_{i}^{\prime}(n-(2n-1))r^{2n-%
2}\right)" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: Observe that $f^{\prime \prime}_1(0) = f^{\prime \prime}_2(0)$.  We compute the difference of third derivatives as follows:
prevtext: and after further calculation,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex47.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{n-1}{2}f^{\prime\prime}_{i}(c)=n-3-\frac{2}{n-1}+\frac{n}{n%
-1}\left(r^{2n-2}(z_{i}-c)+\frac{1}{r^{2n-2}(z_{i}-c)}\right)." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>′′</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Observe that $f^{\prime \prime}_1(0) = f^{\prime \prime}_2(0)$.  We compute the difference of third derivatives as follows:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex48.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{n-1}{2}\left(f^{(3)}_{1}(c)-f^{(3)}_{2}(c)\right)" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex48.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{n}{n-1}\left(r^{2n-2}(z_{1}-c)-r^{2n-2}(z_{2}-c)\right)^{\prime}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex49.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle-\frac{n}{n-1}\left(\frac{1}{r^{2n-2}(z_{2}-c)}-\frac{1}{r^{2n-2}%
(z_{1}-c)}\right)^{\prime}" display="inline"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Since $\Sigma$ is a surface, this implies $\dot{\gamma}$ is an eigenvector of the Weingarten map, which proves the Lemma.  
\end{proof}
Since the compact lines of curvature on any catenoid $\Sigma\subset {\mathbb{R}}^3$ are circles centered on $\ell(\Sigma)$, elementary geometry implies $0\in \ell(\Sigma)$.  
\end{remark}
